frontmatter.title: Computation of Inverse in Extension Fields

children.html: Fpn\mathbb{F}_{p^n}Fpn​
Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​

children.value: , if we directly apply the Extended Euclidean Algorithm or Fermat’s Little Theorem to compute inverses, it requires multiple multiplication operations in

children.html: Fpn\mathbb{F}_{p^n}Fpn​

children.value: , which is computationally expensive. An optimization approach is to convert the inverse computation in the extension field to inverse computation in the base field or a subfield. This conversion introduces a small number of additional multiplication operations, but reduces the overall computational complexity.
Let’s consider a simple case where the base field is

children.value: is converted to an inverse operation in

children.html: Fp\mathbb{F}_{p}Fp​

children.value: , with a constant number (five in this case) of additional multiplication operations in

children.html: Fp\mathbb{F}_{p}Fp​

children.value:
def quadratic_inv(t: K, c0: F):
    if t == K(0):
        raise ValueError("t=0")
    g = K.gen()   # root of f(X)=(X^2 - c0)
    [a0, a1] = t.list()
    a0_sq = a0 * a0
    a1_sq = a1 * a1
    
    scalar = a0_sq - c0 * a1_sq
    scalar_inv = scalar.inverse()

    b0 = scalar_inv * a0
    b1 = scalar_inv * (-a1)
    
    return b0 + b1 * g
This method is not limited to binomial extensions but is applicable to any irreducible polynomial. For example, if we generate

children.html: Fp2\mathbb{F}_{p^2}Fp2​
g(X)=X2+c1X+c0g(X) = X^2 + c_1X + c_0g(X)=X2+c1​X+c0​

[a0c0⋅a1a1a0+c1a1][b0b1]=[10]\begin{bmatrix} a_0 & c_0\cdot a_1 \\ a_1 & a_0+c_1a_1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} b_0 \\ b_1 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[a0​a1​​c0​⋅a1​a0​+c1​a1​​][b0​b1​​]=[10​]

children.value:
def cubic_inv(t: K, w: F):
    [a0, a1, a2] = t.list()
    g = K.gen()
    a0_sq = a0 * a0
    a1_sq = a1 * a1
    a2_w = w * a2
    a0_a1 = a0 * a1

    scalar = a0*a0_sq + w*a1*a1_sq + a2_w * a2_w * a2 - F(3) * a2_w * a0_a1
    scalar_inv = scalar.inverse()
    b0 = scalar_inv * (a0_sq - a1 * a2_w)
    b1 = scalar_inv * (a2_w * a2 - a0_a1)
    b2 = scalar_inv * (a1_sq - a0 * a2)
    return b0 + b1 * g + b2 * g^2
By combining some reusable multiplication operations in

children.html: Fp\mathbb{F}_{p}Fp​

children.value: , we ultimately require 14 multiplication operations in

children.html: Fp\mathbb{F}_{p}Fp​
Fp\mathbb{F}_{p}Fp​

children.value: For quartic extensions, we can still use the approach above, though the complexity of matrix inversion increases rapidly.
We can, of course, convert a quartic extension into two steps of quadratic extensions.

children.html: Fp4=Fp(α)(β)\mathbb{F}_{p^4} = \mathbb{F}_{p}(\alpha)(\beta)Fp4​=Fp​(α)(β)

children.value: Then the first step of the inverse operation converts the inverse in the quartic extension field to an inverse in the quadratic extension field, and finally uses the quadratic extension inverse formula to convert it to an inverse operation in the base field.

children.html: Fp4\mathbb{F}_{p^4}Fp4​

children.value: is a direct quartic extension, but the irreducible polynomial used is a quartic binomial, then we have a more optimized approach (this approach comes from the implementation of RicsZero).

children.value: Inverse Algorithm Based on Frobenius Map

children.label: Inverse Algorithm Based on Frobenius Map

children.value: The core idea of the algorithms above is to convert the inverse operation in the extension field to an inverse operation in the base field.
Based on the Frobenius Map, we can also convert the inverse operation in the extension field to an inverse operation in the base field.

children.html: Fpn\mathbb{F}_{p^n}Fpn​
Frobn:Fpn→FpnFrob_n: \mathbb{F}_{p^n} \to \mathbb{F}_{p^n}Frobn​:Fpn​→Fpn​
Frobn(α)=αpFrob_n(\alpha) = \alpha^{p}Frobn​(α)=αp
α\alphaα

children.value: The Python code is as follows:
As you can see, this algorithm is a general algorithm, and there are no assumptions about the structure of the extension field or the irreducible polynomial.
Optimization of Frobenius Map for Binomial Extension Fields

children.label: Optimization of Frobenius Map for Binomial Extension Fields

children.value: If we only consider binomial extension fields, we can further optimize the computation of the Frobenius Map.
Assume the extension field is defined as:

children.html: αp=(a0+a1β+a2β2+⋯+an−1βn−1)p=a0p+a1pβp+a2pβ2p+⋯+an−1pβp(n−1)=a0+a1βp+a2β2p+⋯+an−1βp(n−1)=a0+a1⋅(βp−1)⋅β+a2⋅(βp−1)2⋅β2+⋯+an−1⋅(βp−1)(n−1)⋅βn−1\begin{aligned} \alpha^p &= (a_0 + a_1\beta + a_2 \beta^2 + \cdots + a_{n-1} \beta^{n-1})^p \\ &= a_0^p + a_1^p\beta^p + a_2^p\beta^{2p} + \cdots + a_{n-1}^p\beta^{p(n-1)} \\ &= a_0 + a_1\beta^p + a_2\beta^{2p} + \cdots + a_{n-1}\beta^{p(n-1)} \\ &= a_0 + a_1\cdot (\beta^{p-1})\cdot \beta + a_2\cdot (\beta^{p-1})^{2}\cdot \beta^2 + \cdots + a_{n-1}\cdot (\beta^{p-1})^{(n-1)} \cdot \beta^{n-1} \end{aligned}αp​=(a0​+a1​β+a2​β2+⋯+an−1​βn−1)p=a0p​+a1p​βp+a2p​β2p+⋯+an−1p​βp(n−1)=a0​+a1​βp+a2​β2p+⋯+an−1​βp(n−1)=a0​+a1​⋅(βp−1)⋅β+a2​⋅(βp−1)2⋅β2+⋯+an−1​⋅(βp−1)(n−1)⋅βn−1​
